Issues.Title: In Ivy, @Input setting order no longer matches the order of their corresponding properties in the class
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package "@angular/core": "9.0.0-rc.5" with Ivy ### Description __Before Ivy__: it was possible to receive `@input` values in a certain order. For example: I have a following component: ```ts @Component({ selector: 'hello', template: `

Hello {{name}}!

` }) export class HelloComponent { public name: string = ""; @Input() set firstName(value: string) { this.name += value; } @Input() set lastName(value: string) { this.name += value; } } ``` In this case, the`firstName` input setter used to run before the `lastName` input setter as their order is defined in the component class. So no matter in what order users provide values to input properties, it was possible to receive them in our desired order: ```html ``` __After Ivy__: I realized that input values are set as they are provided in the template, not by the order of their corresponding properties in the class. For example, using the exact same component in Ivy, we get the following result: ```html ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Angular 8: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-input-order In Ivy: https://ivy.ng-run.com/edit/cOAOZzmer5154DINiEZT?open=app%2Fapp.component.ts ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 


"@angular/core": "9.0.0-rc.5" with Ivy
**Anything else relevant?**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "In Ivy, @Input setting order no longer matches the order of their corresponding properties in the class" (#34322)

Issues.Title: Cannot locally map two libraries and build
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... Yes, this was working correctly in Angular 7. Ran into this issue in Angular 8 as well though. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... Locally mapping libraries that depend upon other libraries cannot find the dependencies correctly. In some cases, I get the following in the parent projects. > ERROR in The target entry-point "Library2" has missing dependencies: > - Library1 In others, I get this: > ERROR: Unexpected value 'OneModule in C:/TFS/Azure/Test/Library1/dist/library/one/library-one.d.ts' imported by the module 'TwoModule in C:/TFS/Azure/Test/Library2/projects/library/two/src/lib/two.module.ts'. Please add a @NgModule annotation. > > An unhandled exception occurred: Unexpected value 'OneModule in C:/TFS/Azure/Test/Library1/dist/library/one/library-one.d.ts' imported by the module 'TwoModule in C:/TFS/Azure/Test/Library2/projects/library/two/src/lib/two.module.ts'. Please add a @NgModule annotation. > > See "C:\Users\\AppData\Local\Temp\ng-MRrgGh\angular-errors.log" for further details. Taking a look, it seems the .d.ts file has no NgModel attribute, which is where this is being imported from. In either case, I cannot use locally linked libraries (**with ivy turned off**). **I can get this to work with ivy turned on but it doesn't allow me to publish these ivy packages** **Is there a way I can disable the Ivy publish denial easily, or will I have to write a tool to modify the package.json that throws that error on publish?** ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [Github Repro](https://github.com/Magn3s1um/ng-bug-report) Pull the above repo. Install in each library, build using ng build @library/one and ng build @library/two. Notice how it doesn't find OneModule as an actual module. ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.5
Node: 12.13.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular:
...
Ivy Workspace:

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.900.0-rc.5
@angular-devkit/core         9.0.0-rc.5
@angular-devkit/schematics   9.0.0-rc.5
@schematics/angular          9.0.0-rc.5
@schematics/update           0.900.0-rc.5
rxjs                         6.5.3
**Anything else relevant?** HI I'm using windows. When I try and locally map Library2 into an angular project, I get this error. This does not happen if I install the libraries from npm (I publish them). This isn't ideal for development when I want to iterate over the library + project combination quickly. Thanks for all your help.

Issues.Title: fix(docs-infra): fix styling of embedded Table-of-Contents
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes the following issues:
- Align text content with caret icon in embedded ToC header.
- Fix display of expand/collapse button at the bottom of embeded ToC.

These were accidentally broken in #32124, while fixing another ToC-related issue. Some CSS rules in `_toc.scss` (e.g. those for `.mat-icon` and `ul.toc-list`) were correctly moved out of the `.toc-inner > button` block, but others (e.g. `&.toc-heading` and `&.toc-more-items`) should not have been moved outside the `.toc-inner > button` block.

_Before:_
![toc-styles before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8604205/70441952-00df2380-1a9e-11ea-8fc7-d141cc8c9045.png)

_After:_
![toc-styles after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8604205/70441953-0177ba00-1a9e-11ea-8af8-d497977009ae.png)

Closes #34300 (as it fixes the same issue in a different way).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(docs-infra): fix styling of embedded Table-of-Contents" (#34312)

Issues.Title: 9.0.0-rc.5: ngStyle border style with undefined values create wrong css properties (with ivy enabled)
Issues.Body:
### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/common with needs ivy enabled ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.2.14 or 9.0.0 with ivy disabled. ### Description Assigning a ngStyle with the value below (in ts file) generates invalid css properties. ```ts style = { "border-top-color": undefined, "border-top-style": undefined, // "border-left-color": undefined, // "border-right-color": undefined, "border-color": "Red", "border-style": "solid", "border-width": "1rem", }; ``` That create a border with the top part invisible. Uncomment `border-left-color` or `border-right-color` make that side black. Commenting the `border-top-*` properties the error disappears. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/j-oliveras/bug-ngstyle Steeps: * `npm install` * `npm start` * Open http://localhost:4200/ I create a stackblitz repo (same code as github repo) that **NOT reproduce** the error (is ivy disabled?). Issues.Title: fix(common): ensure diffing in ngStyle/ngClass correctly emits value changes
Issues.Body:
Prior to this patch, ngStyle/ngClass would accidentally emit value
changes for static (string-based) values even if the value itself had
not changed. This patch ensures that the style/class diffing code is
more strict and when it signals ngClass/ngStyle that there has been a
value change.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(common): ensure diffing in ngStyle/ngClass correctly emits value changes" (#34307)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): various IE issues
Issues.Body:
Since we haven't been running the Ivy tests against IE for a while, we've accumulated some errors and test failures. These changes fix the issues which come from a handful of root causes:

**i18n instructions thrown off by sanitizer:**

While sanitizing on browsers that don't support the `template` element (pretty much only IE), we create an inert document and we insert content into it via `document.body.innerHTML = unsafeHTML`. The problem is that IE appears to parse the HTML passed to `innerHTML` differently, depending on whether the element has been inserted into a document or not. In particular, it seems to split some strings into multiple text nodes, which would've otherwise been a single node. This ended up throwing off some of the i18n code down the line and causing a handful of failures. I've worked around it by creating a new inert `body` element into which the HTML would be inserted.

**Inheriting injectable definition from parent class not working in IE10 JIT mode:**

The way definitions are added in JIT mode is through `Object.defineProperty`, but the problem is that in IE10 properties defined through `defineProperty` won't be inherited which means that inheriting injectable definitions no longer works. These changes add a workaround only for JIT mode where we define a fallback method for retrieving the definition. This isn't ideal, but it should only be required until v10 where we'll no longer support inheriting injectable definitions from undecorated classes.

**Inheritance issues in IE10:**

It looks like most of the inheritance functionality in Ivy wasn't working in JIT mode because we weren't accessing things correctly. These changes fix all of the cases.

**Proxies being used in DebugElement.classes:**

We're currently using proxies to pick up changes to element classes coming outside of Angular. Proxies aren't supported in IE and an error is always thrown. I've reworked the tests where possible and skipped the rest with a TODO to come back and re-enable them once we have some kind of fallback.

**Inconsistent `typeof Node` value:**

We have a couple of cases where we use something like `typeof Node === 'function'` to figure out whether we're in a worker context. This works in most browsers, but IE returns `object` instead of `function`. I've updated all the usages to account for it.

**IE saving the attribute case:**

In `DebugElement.attributes` we return all of the attributes from the underlying DOM node. Most browsers change the attribute names to lower case, but IE preserves the case and since we use camel-cased attributes, the return value was inconsistent. I've changed it to always lower case the attribute names.

**Unable to get own function name:**

When we log DI errors we get the name of the provider via `SomeClass.name`. In IE functions that inherit from other functions don't have their own `name`, but they take the `name` from the lowest parent in the chain, before `Function`. I've added some changes to fall back to parsing out the function name from the function's string form.

**Different attribute order in innerHTML:**

We've got some tests that assert that the generated DOM looks correct. The problem is that IE changes the attribute order in `innerHTML` which caused the tests to fail. I've reworked the relevant tests not to assert directly against `innerHTML`.

**__proto__ not supported:**

IE doesn't support `__proto__`. I've added a fallback based on #34279.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): various IE issues" (#34305)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): various IE issues
Issues.Body:
Since we haven't been running the Ivy tests against IE for a while, we've accumulated some errors and test failures. These changes fix the issues which come from a handful of root causes:

**i18n instructions thrown off by sanitizer:**

While sanitizing on browsers that don't support the `template` element (pretty much only IE), we create an inert document and we insert content into it via `document.body.innerHTML = unsafeHTML`. The problem is that IE appears to parse the HTML passed to `innerHTML` differently, depending on whether the element has been inserted into a document or not. In particular, it seems to split some strings into multiple text nodes, which would've otherwise been a single node. This ended up throwing off some of the i18n code down the line and causing a handful of failures. I've worked around it by creating a new inert `body` element into which the HTML would be inserted.

**Proxies being used in DebugElement.classes:**

We're currently using proxies to pick up changes to element classes coming outside of Angular. Proxies aren't supported in IE and error is always thrown. I've reworked the tests where possible and skipped the rest with a TODO to come back and re-enable them once we have som kind of fallback.

**Inconsistent `typeof Node` value:**

We have a couple of cases where we use something like `typeof Node === 'function'` to figure out whether we're in a worker context. This works in most browsers, but IE returns `object` instead of `function`. I've updated all the usages to account for it.

**IE saving the attribute case:**

In `DebugElement.attributes` we return all of the attributes from the underlying DOM node. Most browsers change the attribute names to lower case, but IE preserves the case and since we use camel-cased attributes, the return value was inconsitent. I've changed it to always lower case the attribute names.

**Unable to get own function name:**

When we log DI errors we get the name of the provider via `SomeClass.name`. In IE functions that inherit from other functions don't have their own `name`, but they take the `name` from the lowest parent in the chain, before `Function`. I've added some changes to fall back to parsing out the function name from the function's string form.

**Different attribute order in innerHTML:**

We've got some tests that assert that the generate DOM looks correct. The problem is that IE changes the attribute order in `innerHTML` which caused the tests to fail. I've reworked the relevant tests not to assert directly against `innerHTML`.

**__proto__ not supported:**

IE doesn't support `__proto__`. I've added a fallback based on #34279.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): various IE issues" (#34304)

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
I create lazy loaded components with a module and a routing module to separate routing functionality. I wish to import the Common Module and a custom Material Design module into example-module but it will only accept being imported into example-routing-module.

The following error message is thrown in the console 'Cannot bind to '' as it is not a known property.'

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
Create a component with an associated module and routing module.

### Reproduction Steps**
Use the Angular CLI to generate a new component and then create a module with the -- routing flag to separate routing functionality. 

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
Expected: Common Module and Material Module should be imported into the main module and not the routing module.
Actual: Application will only load if I import associated import into the associated routing module.

## üåç  Your Environment
Node v13.2.0
Angular CLI 8.3.20
OS win32 x64

Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->

- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->

No

### Description

Different machine and different node version build with different artifacts. (different file hash and different file content)

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

* install docker (my docker version is mac docker desktop community 2.1.0.5(40693))
* `git clone https://github.com/xiaoxiangmoe/angular-hash-problem.git`  (this repo is an empty repo create by ng-cli new)
* `cd angular-hash-problem`
* `docker run --rm --interactive --tty --mount type=bind,source="$(pwd)",target=/workspace node:13.3.0-alpine /bin/sh`
* `cd workspace/`
* `yarn build --prod`

it generate:

```
Generating ES5 bundles for differential loading...
ES5 bundle generation complete.

chunk {0} runtime-es2015.e59a6cd8f1b6ab0c3f29.js (runtime) 1.45 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {0} runtime-es5.e59a6cd8f1b6ab0c3f29.js (runtime) 1.45 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {2} polyfills-es2015.58725a5910daef768ca8.js (polyfills) 36 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {3} polyfills-es5.c7f38740d119d1d125aa.js (polyfills-es5) 125 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {1} main-es2015.9f2a69a2a7ce2c1f668b.js (main) 215 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {1} main-es5.9f2a69a2a7ce2c1f668b.js (main) 258 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {4} styles.0e4338761429b4eb16ac.css (styles) 0 bytes [initial] [rendered]
Date: 2019-12-10T03:43:32.228Z - Hash: 6aed27717e970881a87c - Time: 59765ms
```
when we build it in same node version in mac. it generate same result.

but if we build it in different node version in docker. it generate different hash, for example node:10.16.1-alpine

```
Generating ES5 bundles for differential loading...
ES5 bundle generation complete.

chunk {0} runtime-es2015.e59a6cd8f1b6ab0c3f29.js (runtime) 1.45 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {0} runtime-es5.e59a6cd8f1b6ab0c3f29.js (runtime) 1.45 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {2} polyfills-es2015.58725a5910daef768ca8.js (polyfills) 36 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {3} polyfills-es5.c7f38740d119d1d125aa.js (polyfills-es5) 125 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {1} main-es2015.9f2a69a2a7ce2c1f668b.js (main) 215 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {1} main-es5.9f2a69a2a7ce2c1f668b.js (main) 258 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {4} styles.0e4338761429b4eb16ac.css (styles) 0 bytes [initial] [rendered]
Date: 2019-12-10T04:00:33.003Z - Hash: 6aed27717e970881a87c - Time: 29734ms
```

---

also, if we run `yarn build` without `--prod`, we will found full directory in `main-es5.js`:

```
function _(module, exports, __webpack_require__) {
    module.exports = __webpack_require__(
    /*! /Users/zhaojinxiang/codes/angular-hash-problem/src/main.ts */
    "./src/main.ts");
    /***/
  }
```

if we move project from `~/codes/angular-hash-problem` into `~/repos/angular-hash-problem`, it will generate different artifacts

---

in conclusion:

* crossing operating system: stable
* crossing node version: unstable
* crossing directory: stable in `--prod` and unstable in `--prod=false`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "angular build artifacts is unstable" (#16402)

Issues.Title: Service worker failing with i18n because of absolute paths in ngsw-config.json
Issues.Body: # üêû Bug report ### Commands - ng generate service-worker - ng add @angular/pwa ### Is this a regression? No, the issue seems to be there from a long time. ### Description Currently, the `ngsw-config.json` generated with `ng g service-worker` or `ng add @angular/pwa` references absolute paths (eg. `/index.html`, `/*.css`...). It will work fine if the app is deployed in the root directory (ie. with ` Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.5 Node: 12.13.1 OS: darwin x64 Angular: 9.0.0-rc.5 ... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core ... forms, language-service, localize, material ... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router ... service-worker Ivy Workspace: Yes Package Version ------------------------------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.900.0-rc.5 @angular-devkit/build-angular 0.900.0-rc.5 @angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr 0.900.0-rc.5 @angular-devkit/build-optimizer 0.900.0-rc.5 @angular-devkit/build-webpack 0.900.0-rc.5 @angular-devkit/core 9.0.0-rc.5 @angular-devkit/schematics 9.0.0-rc.5 @ngtools/webpack 9.0.0-rc.5 @schematics/angular 9.0.0-rc.5 @schematics/update 0.900.0-rc.5 ng-packagr 9.0.0-rc.3 rxjs 6.5.3 typescript 3.6.4 webpack 4.41.2 **Anything else relevant?** The fix is easy: just remove the leading slash of all paths in [`ngsw-config.json` template](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/schematics/angular/service-worker/files/ngsw-config.json.template) (including the `index` property).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Service worker failing with i18n because of absolute paths in ngsw-config.json" (#16390)

Issues.Title: "Cannot read property 'loadChildren' of undefined" error on first compilation only
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 9rc1 ### Description When compiling project since Angular 9 rc2 & Angular 8 lastest releases, first ```ng serve``` or ```ng build``` always fail. But there's a fix: for ```ng serve```, when commenting any code line, error disappear by itself and all next compilations work, even after restoring commented code. A clear and concise description of the problem... ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I only managed to reproduce this bug in a real life project. It did work with first versions of Angular 9 rc, and started having this bugs with rc2. Now the problem also occurs with angular 8.3.20. This is the only error message, no clearer description from Angular CLI, so I have absolutely no idea where the error comes from... ## üî• Exception or Error 


ERROR in Cannot read property 'loadChildren' of undefined
## üåç Your Environment 



Angular CLI: 8.3.20

**Anything else relevant?** I know minimal reproduction should be included: however I could'nt see what makes this happen, and was unable to reproduce the bug with a simple project. I have nothing more than this error message that disappears by itself after first compilation...

Issues.Title: Angular complains about missing `index.ts` when it is there #16386
Issues.Body:
This is in reference to:
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/16386

The error message:
> ERROR in ./node_modules/@fireflysemantics/slice/index.ts
Module build failed (from ./node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js):
Error: /home/ole/Temp/sph/node_modules/@fireflysemantics/slice/index.ts is missing from the TypeScript compilation. Please make sure it is in your tsconfig via the 'files' or 'include' property.
The missing file seems to be part of a third party library. TS files in published libraries are often a sign of a badly packaged library. Please open an issue in the library repository to alert its author and ask them to package the library using the Angular Package Format (https://goo.gl/jB3GVv).
    at AngularCompilerPlugin.getCompiledFile (/home/ole/Temp/sph/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.js:900:23)
    at /home/ole/Temp/sph/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/loader.js:41:31
    at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:85:5)

Says to include `index.ts` in:
> Please make sure it is in your tsconfig via the 'files' or 'include' property.

This is confusing because IIUC it should not be included in the package at all.  After I removed it from the package, the application started compiling fine.  So  I assume that it just means that packages should not include `index.ts` in the root folder at all?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular complains about missing `index.ts` when it is there #16386" (#16388)

Issues.Title: how to remove unused code form js files build by angular?

Issues.Title: How to prevent build with there are tslint errors?
Issues.Body:
Question
Hi everyone,

I am working in an angular 8 app that has tslint rules defined. The rules are working very nice when developers are coding but the problem that I have is the ng serve and ng build allow developers to build the app although there are TSlint errors. is there a way to force Tslint rules when the project is building so developers have to fix the TSlint errors before they can see in the browser?

best
Hmendezm
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to prevent build with there are tslint errors?" (#16391)

Issues.Title: Adding a dependency with yarn while serving the app breaks ngcc generated files import
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [X] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.2.14 ### Description When running Angular 9 with `ng serve` then installing a dependency with `yarn`, `yarn` will overwrite angular dependencies' `package.json` files and remove `__ivy_ngcc__` files generated by `ngcc` when `ng serve` starts. This produces an error on `ng serve` as it can't find IVy generated files like `./node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js` Maybe `ng serve` could watch for these files and rebuild them if they disappear? ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR in ./node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js
Module build failed: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/Users/r/Desktop/demo/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js'
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Adding a dependency with yarn while serving the app breaks ngcc generated files import" (#16397)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): require to run in a project if the help flag is present
Issues.Body:
Closes: #16241

Currently, when running `ng generate --help` or any other command (e.g. `ng add --help`), it throws such exception:
```
An unhandled exception occurred: Unable to locate a workspace file for workspace path.
See "/tmp/ng-lBY5ie/angular-errors.log" for further details.
```

Angular CLI requires commands to be run in an Angular project only if there is no `help` flag.

This PR provides a small fix that removes condition allowing to always validate scope and throw:
`The <command> command requires to be run in an Angular project`

Except of unhandled exception.

Otherwise it would need to edit more code.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular/cli): require to run in a project if the help flag is present" (#16396)

Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ X ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Please add a @NgModule annotation.` But this is only happening when my lib is pre-build with Ivy option set to `true`, otherwise everything is fine. A clear and concise description of the problem... ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - `ng new my-app` - `ng g lib my-lib` - build `my-lib` - import `my-lib` into `my-app`s module - run `ng xi18n` for `my-app` ## üî• Exception or Error

## üåç Your Environment 



`@angular/* version 9.0.0-rc-4 or 0.900.0-rc-4`
**Anything else relevant?** Nope

Issues.Title: Resolve typescript paths when compiling libraries
Issues.Body:
If we setup the typescript `paths` option for libraries the libraries get compiled without resolving the paths.  For example if we declared a path like this:

```
      "@app/*": ["projects/my-lib/src/lib/*"] 

```

And build.  The compiled fesm2015 will look like this:

```
import { Test } from '@app/test';

```
I have been using typescript transform paths for this in the past, but I was hoping Angular Library support would have it baked in.  

https://www.npmjs.com/package/typescript-transform-paths
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Resolve typescript paths when compiling libraries" (#16383)

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): handle aliased or existing environment import
Issues.Body:
Closes: #16226

I debugged a little bit that issue. The exception `Cannot read property 'length' of undefined` wasn't really informative thus I had to find out where this exception was actually thrown. All ways led me to the `Chunk` class and the `insertLeft` method that used `buffer`'s variable `length` property. The `buffer` was `undefined`, that's why that exception was thrown. It was `undefined` because there is no way to check if `environment` is already imported.

This PR adds the ability to handle the already existing "environment" import or the named one.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@schematics/angular): handle aliased or existing environment import" (#16377)

Issues.Title: The command ng serve is not responding to changes to ng module
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command

- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Description

`ng serve` either is not responding to changes made to the `declarations` property of an `NgModule`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
1. `ng new pokemon --routing=false --style=css`
2. `ng generate component pokedex`
3. set up `pokedex` to be used by the root component
4. `ng serve`
5. remove `pokedex` from the `declarations` field of the `NgModule` in `app.module.ts`

### Expected
The app crashes
### Actual
The app continues working

### Additional Information
Restarting `ng serve` fixes the issue.
This also works vice-versa, so if the application is crashing due to `pokedex` _not_ being in the `declarations` of `app.module.ts`, adding it without restarting `ng serve` will still be crashing.

## üåç Your Environment
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25158423/70344220-fe669a80-180d-11ea-87ef-afb74aacd87a.png)

## Demo
I've created a demo project [here](https://github.com/wagnermaciel/Pokedex).
To reproduce this issue
1. `git clone https://github.com/wagnermaciel/Pokedex.git`
2. `npm install`
3. `ng serve`
4. Go to http://localhost:4200/pikachu
4. remove `PokedexComponent` from the `declarations` of the `NgModule` in `src/app.app.module.ts`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The command ng serve is not responding to changes to ng module" (#16376)

Issues.Title: fix(text-field): correctly check _initialHeight
Issues.Body:
TypeScript 3.7 flags the assignment on line 250 because `style.height` must not be `null`.

The underlying reason though appears to be that the comparison checks against `=== undefined`, where the field only declares `null` as an option. The field is not initialized, so `undefined` is the correct value to compare to and type to use.

Issues.Title: feat(material-experimental): initial prototype of mdc-form-field
Issues.Body:
Creates the initial prototype of form-field based on MDC text-field.

A few things that required some special handling in terms of extra CSS:
* MDC text-field bottom-lines are limited to `input` and `textarea`. We want them to work always and to also cover prefixes and suffixes.
* MDC text-field does not have a real standard appearance that works well for inputs and textarea's.
* MDC text-field relies on special class being applied if textarea is the control. This doesn't match our model of "abstract" form field controls (so we needed custom handling; see SCSS comments)

Based on demo comparisons and unit test comparisons there are no breaking changes in terms of API and features, except that prefixes and suffixes do not work properly in the outline appearance. This requires some more thoughts and most likely upstream changes in MDC text-field. I could imagine this being something we can tackle in follow-ups's as the PR is already quite large.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(material-experimental): initial prototype of mdc-form-field" (#17903)

Issues.Title: Angular Mat Overlay removes previous overlays
Issues.Body:
In the updated Mat Overlay (introduced in Angular v8), previous overlays are removed when a new overlay is opened.
[Here](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/27fae292721bcc48b68c16fe5c7ac5e928eaa57d/src/cdk/overlay/overlay-container.ts#L58) is the line.

**Issue**
When using multiple angular applications together (micro-frontend), the reference to overlays are kept in memory [here](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/7.3.x/src/cdk/overlay/overlay-container.ts#L40) but, the element is itself removed from DOM by other micro app. Consequently, the dialog is not shown.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Mat Overlay removes previous overlays" (#17899)

Issues.Title: datepicker memory leak
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. go to https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/examples
2. open datepicker and close multiple times
3. each open and close action generate **135KB** memory leak.

The more times we open and close datepicker, the more memory are allocated.  
Garbage collector does not clear all allocated memory.

![](https://i.imgur.com/5BQgg95.jpg)


 
 
#### Expected Behavior
datepicker without memory leaks

#### Actual Behavior
memory leaks

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14, 9.0.0-rc.5
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3, 9.0.0-rc.5
- Browser(s): Chrome 78.0.3904.108
- Operating System: Fedora 31
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "datepicker memory leak" (#17896)

Issues.Title: YouTube player component triggers change detection every 250ms
Issues.Body:
#### Bug:

Currently, the YouTube player component triggers change detection every 250ms.
When a `YT.Player` instance is created, `setInterval` is called in it.

#### What is the expected behavior?

The YouTube player component should trigger change detection only by events.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-xnpnny?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
@angular/youtube-player 8.2.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "YouTube player component triggers change detection every 250ms" (#17882)

Issues.Title: fix(youtube-player): avoid setInterval change detection when player is created
Issues.Body: When we create a `Player` object for the `youtube-player` component, the YouTube API kicks off a 250ms `setInterval` which will trigger change detection even if the video is passive on the page. These change run the initialization code outside the `NgZone` so that doesn't happen.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(youtube-player): avoid setInterval change detection when player is created" (#17894)

Issues.Title: DOM nodes not cleaned up if view container is destroyed before Dialog close animation completes or starts
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
When a Dialog is closed before the close animation completes the overlay container is not destroyed. This is similar to https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16284 which resulted in a PR https://github.com/angular/components/pull/16309.

But this PR doesn't fix the edge case where the animation never even starts before it is destroyed. It assumes the animation has to at least start which is where the setTimeout was added. The solution most likely needs to create the timeout inside the close() function but not inside the animation observable.

Specifically I see the close function start, end and then the page fully destroys before the animation observable even gets a change to start (never makes it to the .subscribe segment of `this._containerInstance.animationStateChanged`. 

#### What is the expected behavior?

I would expect that when the close() function is called that the timeout is set immediately (not in an observable) as a fallback in case any part of the animation close observable (even it's start) doesn't occur which will still call `this._overlayRef.dispose()`.

#### What is the current behavior?

Current behavior is the overlay DOM elements are still present after a path change while a modal is still open.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

This is still a good place to reproduce this: https://stackblitz.com/github/mike88ua/redirect_from_dialog
Simple steps are open a dialog and generate a path change while the dialog is still open that is a local Angular path change to some place in the same angular app. The Overlay DOM elements are still present.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?

Avoid overlay fragments being left on the page.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

* Angular: 7.3.x 
* Material: 7.3.x
* Browser: Chrome

#### Is there anything else we should know?

I will test a version of this change and provide a PR if it works correctly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DOM nodes not cleaned up if view container is destroyed before Dialog close animation completes or starts" (#17891)

Issues.Title: Wrong overlay pane position after anchor scrolling in mobile Safari
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://angular-overlay-anchor.stackblitz.io
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-overlay-anchor

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open on a real iOS device via Safari
2. Click "Toggle overlay"
3. Click "Anchor link" => overlay is closed, window is scrolled to anchor
4. Click "Toggle overlay" again
 
#### Expected Behavior

Overlay position is correct

#### Actual Behavior

Overlay pane with anchor link is in the wrong position (not connected to toggle)

#### Environment

- Angular: 
stackblitz is using v8.2.14, the issue persists with latest v9.0.0-rc4
- CDK/Material: 
stackblitz is using v8.2.3, the issue persists with latest v9.0.0-rc4
- Browser(s): 
mobile Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): 
Tested on iOS 12.4 with iPhone 8plus
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Wrong overlay pane position after anchor scrolling in mobile Safari" (#17890)

Issues.Title: MatTab: selectedTabChange should not fire when the tab is changed programmatically
Issues.Body:
There should be a way to differentiate **between a UI and a programmaticcally induced tab change**. As of now, both cause the selectedTabChange: EventEmitter<MatTabChangeEvent> to emit.

My case is pretty simple: I want to display the currently opened Tab in the URL:

somePage?openedTab=1
somePage?openedTab=2

But I also want the corresponding tab to open when a URL pointing to a specific tab is navigated to. **Ideally, the [selectedIndex] input should not cause (selectedTabChange) to fire**.

Does this make sense?

Material 8.2.3, Angular 8.2.11
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatTab: selectedTabChange should not fire when the tab is changed programmatically" (#17889)

Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: [@angular/cdk/drag-drop 8.2.3] Wrong place holder position when list is rorated
Issues.Body:
#### Bug:

@angular/cdk/drag-drop 8.2.3
When dragging an item into a drop list that has been rotated, the place holder does not appear at the proper location.
It rotation is 180 and we move the item to the top, place holder moves to the bottom.

![Capture d‚Äô√©cran du 2019-12-05 15-41-44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58560323/70245084-cb70c800-1775-11ea-936e-61b7efcc56a8.png)

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

Very easy to reproduce from the "**cdk-drag-drop-custom-placeholder-example**" from "**https://material.angular.io/cdk/drag-drop/examples**".

Just add "transform: rotate(180deg);" in the "**.example-list**" class.

**https://stackblitz.com/angular/jbkglkkdddn**

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

@angular/cdk/drag-drop 8.2.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[@angular/cdk/drag-drop 8.2.3] Wrong place holder position when list is rorated" (#17880)
